markdownRemark.html:
After studying in the previous chapters, we have learned the basic knowledge of developing complex interfaces. Next, we will gradually expand the previous Table and practice the corresponding knowledge points.

Table that needs to be roughly implemented:

It can be seen that compared with the previous Table function points, the specific requirements are as follows:

  1. Add fields
  2. Inline editing
  3. Make necessary supplementary explanations for related fields
  4. Age over 18, gender must lose
  5. The age input range must be greater than 1 and less than 100
  6. Age can be sorted
  7. The name must be entered, and the primary key and unique
  8. Mailbox suffix is ​​automatically filled
  9. There is a query bar, searchable
  10. Add action buttons

Similarly, we start with the DataSet combined with the data to be displayed to expand.

Function extension

It can be drawn from the interface that we have expanded three new fields: age (age), mailbox (email), and join date (startDate).

  1. Initially add field configuration to the fields array to complete the first point.

    {
name:'age',
type:'number',
label:'Age',
},
{
name:'email',
type:'string',
label:'Mailbox',
},
{
name:'startDate',
type:'date',
label:'Join Date',
}
  2. Table supports inline editing. The edit component carrier is Table, we check the Table component API, add the editor property to the columns object to achieve in-line editing.
Attribute name Description Type
editor Editor, when set to true, it will automatically match the editor according to the field type. If you are not editable, please use the false value instead of adding disabled to the control. FormField | ((record, name) => FormField | boolean) | boolean 
[
  {name:'name', editor: true },
  {name:'age', editor: true },
  {name:'sex', editor: true },
  {name:'email', editor:true },
  {name:'code', editor: true },
  {name:'startDate', editor: true },
  {name:'active', editor: true },
]
  1. Supplementary explanation of related fields. The processing object is a field, and the help attribute is available in the API. Improve the corresponding field configuration.
Attribute name Description Type
help Extra information, often used to prompt string
 
{
  name:'name',
  type:'string',
  label:'Name',
  help:'Primary key, distinguish users',
},
{
  name:'age',
  type:'number',
  label:'Age',
  help:'User age, can be sorted',
},
{
  name:'email',
  type:'string',
  label:'Mailbox',
  help:'User mailbox, can be automatically completed',
},

Realization effect:

  1. If the age is greater than 18, the gender field must be entered. Analyzing the requirements, you need to dynamically process the gender field configuration, you can use the dynamicProps mentioned in the previous chapter.
{
  name:'sex',
  ...
  computedProps: {
    required: ({ record }) => record.get('age')> 18,
  },
  1. The age input range must be greater than 1 and less than 100. Common component libraries need to be judged and processed during input, here we can also use the field attribute configuration-min / max. Configurable type: field name | number | date.
Attribute name Description Type
max Maximum value. fieldName points to the fieldName value of the current record as the maximum value. BigNumber.Value | MomentInput | fieldName
min Minimum value. fieldName points to the fieldName value of the current record as the minimum value. BigNumber.Value | MomentInput | fieldName

Here we modify the age field:

{
  name:'age',
  type:'number',
  label:'Age',
  max: 100,
  min: 1,
  step: 1,
  help:'User age, can be sorted',
},
  1. The age field supports table sorting. The processing object here is in the table, and the sortable attribute is available when viewing the document.
Attribute name Description Type Default value
sortable Whether it can be sorted (back-end request sorting, front-end sorting please customize the header to implement it yourself) boolean false 
{name:'age', sortable: true, editor: true },
  1. The name must be entered, and the primary key and unique. View field props to modify the name field configuration.
{
  name:'name',
  type:'string',
  label:'Name',
  unique: true, // unique index or joint unique index group name can be edited only if added to ensure the uniqueness of the field or field group
  help:'Primary key, distinguish users',
  required: true,
},
  1. The mailbox suffix is ​​automatically filled.

The specific performance is that the existing mailbox suffix is ​​automatically filled when input. The component we commonly use here is AutoComlpete. The data source of the mailbox suffix can be written to death at the front end or inquired and maintained at the back end.

Here we do a disassembly of the implementation steps:

1. The inline editor matches the EmailField component by default according to the type, we need to modify it to the AutoComlpete component
2. Configure the auto-completion data source for the AutoComlpete component, corresponding to the options property
3. Process AutoComlpete input focus acquisition event and determine whether a suffix is ​​required

a. Modify the editor property of the email column to replace the default editor:

{
  name:'email',
  editor: () => {
    return (
      <AutoComplete
        onFocus={handleValueChange}
        onInput={handleValueChange}
        options={emailOptionDS}
      />
    );
  },
},

b. Process the data source emailOptionDS (this is similar to the Select component data source operation, which will be explained in detail later):

const emailOptionDS = useMemo(() => {
  return new DataSet({
    fields: [
      {
        name:'value',
        type:'string',
      },
      {
        name:'meaning',
        type:'string',
      },
    ],
  });
}, []);

c. Handle events on the component and load data for the data source emailOptionDS:

const handleValueChange = useCallback((v) => {
  const {value} = v.target;
  const suffixList = ['@qq.com','@163.com','@hand-china.com'];
  if (value.indexOf('@') !== -1) {
   // If the input value contains @ do not configure data, customize the input
    emailOptionDS.loadData([]);
  } else {
    emailOptionDS.loadData(
      suffixList.map((suffix) => ({
        value: `${value}${suffix}`,
        meaning: `${value}${suffix}`,
      })),
    );
  }
}, [emailOptionDS]);

After processing, edit the mailbox field to see the effect:

  1. Configure query bar for Table and support query conditions. Here it is applied to DataSet queryFields combined with Table queryBar attribute, queryFields usage is the same as fields:
Attribute name Description Type
queryFields Query field attribute array, internally generate queryDataSet, priority is lower than queryDataSet attribute, see Field Props object[]

We configure three query conditions: name, age, email:

queryFields: [
  {
    name:'name',
    type:'string',
    label:'Name',
  },
  {
    name:'age',
    type:'number',
    label:'Age',
    max: 100,
    step: 1,
  },
  {
    name:'email',
    type:'string',
    label:'Mailbox',
    help:'User mailbox, can be automatically completed',
  }
],

At this time, the corresponding rendering of the interface is as follows:

Check the Table queryBar property, the default type is normal, let's try professionalBar:

Attribute name Description Type Default value
queryBar Query bar, optional value is hook or built-in type: filterBar | professionalBar | advancedBar | normal | bar | none string | ({ dataSet, queryDataSet, buttons, pagination, queryFields, queryFieldsLimit }) => ReactNode normal 
queryBar="professionalBar"

You can see that the corresponding search bar and the number of rows we want to display are still different. Find the API to get:

Attribute name Description Type
queryFieldsLimit The number of query fields displayed in the header, and the query fields that exceed the limit are put into the pop-up window number 
queryFieldsLimit={2}

final effect:

You can try to modify queryBar to other types, and take a look at different preset query interactions. If it does not meet the product requirements, it also supports customization and global configuration.

  1. Add operation buttons. This section is convenient for teaching. The following 8 buttons are added to the configuration Table buttons:
Attribute name Description Type
buttons Function buttons, built-in buttons can add afterClick hooks, used to perform actions other than the default behavior, optional values: add | delete | remove | save | query | reset | expandAll | collapseAll | export or an array or custom buttons, the array is optional value string + button configuration property object string \ 
buttons={['add','query','save','delete','reset', toDataButton, toJSONDataButton, setQueryParamButton]}
  1. Add
  2. Query
  3. Save
  4. Delete
  5. Reset
  6. toDataButton-tableDS.toData()
  7. toJSONDataButton-tableDS.toJSONData()
  8. setQueryParamButton-tableDS.setQueryParameter('customPara','test')

The first five are preset button types, and the built-in package corresponds to the meaning logic. The last three are to demonstrate custom logic trigger buttons:

const [consoleValue, setConsoleValue] = useState('');
const toDataButton = (
  <Button onClick={() => setConsoleValue(tableDS.toData())}>
    toData
  </Button>
);
const toJSONDataButton = (
  <Button onClick={() => setConsoleValue(tableDS.toJSONData())}>
    toJSONData
  </Button>
);
const setQueryParamButton = (
  <Button onClick={() => tableDS.setQueryParameter('customPara','test')}>
    setQueryParameter
  </Button>
);

Output verification

Here we will use CodeArea components are displayed.

import {
  CodeArea
} from 'choerodon-ui/pro';
// 引入格式化器，注意使用模块的默认导出
import JSONFormatter from 'choerodon-ui/pro/lib/code-area/formatters/JSONFormatter';

//return中添加
<CodeArea
  style={{ height: 280 }}
  formatter={JSONFormatter}
  value={JSON.stringify(consoleValue)}
/>

Output display content:

  1. Query event query parameter in DataSet events
  2. toDataButton & toJSONDataButton calling method
  3. Submit transport create type parameters

First we applied the DataSet events event:

// DS event callback
events: {
  load: ({ dataSet }) => {
    console.log('Loading complete', dataSet)
  },
  query: ({ params, data }) => setConsoleValue({params, data}),
}
  • load-the event after the data is loaded
  • query-query event, return value false will prevent query

More events -events.

Therefore, after the initial query, we output the observed paging query parameters.

Click toDataButton or toJSONDataButton to view the corresponding output:

  • toData()-converted to normal data, excluding deleted data
  • toJSONData()-Converted to json data for submission

The output of toJSONData() is [], it can be concluded that there is no submitted data. This involves the dataToJSON attribute mentioned in the previous chapter. Modify the DataSet dataToJSON to "all" and click the button:

Verify setting query parameters:

  1. Enter content in the query bar component, and click query:
  1. Click the setQueryParameter button, click the query:

It can be seen that the default parameters are all processed into the data object.

The remaining preset button behaviors can be operated and output by yourself to check.

The demo case only has a query interface. Operations such as saving and sorting are only for data output demonstration.

This chapter has advanced practice of Table, and the next chapter will practice the Pro Form component.
